repnme.cdata!:
Central America - Nicaragua and Honduras
            Corazon Transboundary Biosphere Reserve Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Nicaragua and Honduras
            Corazon Transboundary Biosphere Reserve Project for Central
            America were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to global environment outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the development of operational
            tools that take into account the local socio-environmental
            realities is critical to ensuring that operations in
            difficult contexts can be executed in reasonable times.
            Direct sub-project implementation by local governments and
            communities requires previous investments in capacity
            building. Assessment of operational risks under bi-national
            projects must take into account overall political conditions
            and should offer options to surpass barriers and ensure
            continuity of activities. Understanding the indigenous Cosmo
            vision is central to the participation of indigenous peoples
            in projects' execution and to the sustainability of
            interventions. Minimum of 13 percent of the total investment
            is required to cover the costs of adequate monitoring of
            sub-projects in remote areas. Setting explicit targets for
            women participation in implementation of sub-projects in
            indigenous communities ensures their involvement and
            promotes empowerment. The Program Assessment of the Regional
            Environmental Program (PROARCA) and global environment
            facility (GEF) tracking tools can be adapted to better
            capture the socio-environmental conditions of local
            protected areas.

repnme.cdata!:
Central America - Nicaragua and Honduras
            Corazon Transboundary Biosphere Reserve Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Nicaragua and Honduras Corazon Transboundary Biosphere
            Reserve Project is to improve the national and binational
            management of the area of the Corazon Transboundary
            Biosphere Reserve (CTBR), respecting the rights of
            traditional populations. The closing of the project will be
            extended from from August 1, 2012 to December 15, 2012. The
            purpose of the extension is to ensure that the results of
            the project are adequately measured and that the lessons
            learned are captured and disseminated. The reallocation of
            grant proceeds is thus needed to ensure that Technical
            Assistance (TA) and Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E)
            expenditures related to implementation of subprojects are
            accounted for consistent with disbursement categories
            specified in the grant agreement. This reallocation does not
            impact the amount of funding approved per component, and
            specifically funding approved for subprojects and grants.
            The reallocation only affects the categories of expenditure
            as defined in the grant agreement. This will be the first
            extension of the project.

            CORAZÃN TRANSBOUNDARY BIOSPHERE RESERVE P

repnme.cdata!:
Central America - Nicaragua and Honduras
            Corazon Transboundary Biosphere Reserve Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Nicaragua and Honduras Corazon Transboundary Biosphere
            Reserve Project is to improve the national and binational
            management of the area of the Corazon Transboundary
            Biosphere Reserve (CTBR), respecting the rights of
            traditional populations. Given the difficulties experienced
            with implementation of this project, and given results to
            date, approval is being requested for a level one
            restructuring, which will involve: 1) a change in the
            objective that will eliminate binational commitments, which
            are not achievable under the current political climate and
            in the project timeframe, while maintaining the overarching
            goal of preserving the cross-boundary Corazon Reserve; 2)
            simplification of project design to focus on activities and
            components that are progressing well and where results have
            been achieved; 3) reallocation of funds, within original
            executing agency allocation, from non-performing components
            to those under which implementation mechanisms are
            functional, and where momentum to complete the proposed
            objectives has been built; and 4) revision of the results
            framework and monitoring arrangements to better capture and
            monitor the impacts of the project on conservation
            objectives of the CTBR. The restructuring proposal does not
            include an extension of the project's closing date.
